Hi,

I think you need to deploy both your jar and the JUnit jar on the target
system.
If you want the jar to be runnable I think you also need to add a classpath
reference
to the JUnit.jar in the manifest. Try googling for "manifest" and
"classpath".

I have never bothered with manifest classpaths. I generally invoke java with
the jars
I need on the classpath and specify which main I want to run like so:
java -cp lib/JUnit.jar:lib/MyJar.jar somepackage.MyMainClass

I hope this helps.
/J

On 2/14/07, Thomas L Roche <tlroche@...> wrote:
>
>   Slightly offtopic, but since it's something that OP probably runink the
> into, and I didn't see it answered in the FAQ, I thought I'd ask:
> how to include JUnit JARs with JARed test code? What I mean:
>
> I'm automating some tests on a legacy batch-mode app that runs
> remotely. This app runs headlessly, emitting tons 'o files to a
> filespace, so basically I'm automating
>
> * invoking the app (setting up its inputs)
>
> * waiting for it to finish
>
> * verifying the output
>
> First I wrote some classes to setup for and invoke the app. I know
> enough Ant to JAR this code up, so I wrote a build.xml (in eclipse)
> for that, built the JAR, deployed it to one of the app's boxes (this
> is the kind of app that bogs down one's laptop if run locally), and
> ran it with `java -jar ...`, so I know that works.
>
> Then I wrote a JUnit test that calls the code that calls the app, and
> rebuilt the JAR (from eclipse). Eclipse compiled the new JUnit-using
> class OK, and included that class in the JAR it built, but the JAR
> does not contain junit.jar or any of its classes. So to deploy the
> new JAR, I just unzipped junit.jar on top of my JAR's contents,
> changed the Main-Class in its manifest, and re-JARed, deployed, and ran.
>
> That worked, but ugly. How best to tell Ant to include make available
> either <project name>/lib/junit.jar or its contents in the output JAR?
>
>  
>
